Award.AwardTitle: Combining Prescriptive and Descriptive Decision Theory for Counter-terrorism Decisions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the Principal Investigator will develop decision analytic methods for multiple decision makers that prescribe one decision maker's decisions while descriptively modeling the decisions of the other decision makers. Decision analysis and game theory have been used extensively to assist in making counter-terrorism decisions. Recently, methods have been proposed to allow treatment of defender decisions, attacker decisions, and uncertainties in one decision model. However, these combined approaches assume that both the attacker and defender are rational decision makers. The rationality assumption is appropriate for the defender as the decision analyst is working in a prescriptive mode to help the defender make a rational and optimal decision. Descriptive decision theory focuses on how real people actually think and behave. Such models are judged by their validity in predicting the actual choices people make and capture many of the ways in which people deviate from the rational, prescriptive ideal. These theories are more appropriate for modeling the attacker's decision. This research will require the development of algorithms that can solve complex influence diagrams with multiple decision makers using prescriptive theories for the defender and descriptive theories for the attacker. We will also develop descriptive decision models for multi-attribute decisions and incorporate them in the prescriptive/descriptive approach.

In terms of broader impacts, this research will benefit the field of homeland security by incorporating more realistic models of attacker behavior while still providing the optimal, rational prescribed action of the defender. It will also benefit general decision theory. The approach is applicable to all decision situations where there are multiple decision makers and an analyst is attempting to prescriptively help one of them make better decisions under uncertainty while modeling the decisions made by the other decision makers. Such situations occur in competitive bargaining and negotiation, marketing and strategy, as well as other general business decisions. Furthermore, while the focus of this research is to prescriptively help one side make better decisions faced with a descriptive model of the other side, there is the potential for this approach to be used in a descriptive science such as economics or political science, where the researcher believes one player in a game is best modeled as rational while the other is best modeled as boundedly rational. The results of this research will be disseminated to both prescriptive and descriptive decision researchers to show that the true power of these methods is found when they are brought together. We will develop iPad software to construct and analyze such models graphically through an intuitive touch interface. This could significantly increase the number of people exposed to this research and the methodologies it integrates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Counter-terrorism decisions have been an intense area of research in recent years with researchers using either decision analysis or game theory. However, each of these approaches has commonly assumed that the attacker is maximizing their expected utility, the leading model of rational decision making. Experimental research shows that human beings do not make decisions by maximizing expected utility without aid, but instead deviate in specific ways such as loss aversion or likelihood insensitivity. In this project, we modified existing methods for counter-terrorism decisions, keeping expected utility as the defender’s paradigm to seek for the rational decision, but descriptively modelling the attacker’s loss aversion and likelihood insensitivity. We studied the effects of this approach on the decision whether to screen containers entering the US for radioactive materials. We found that the defender’s optimal decision is sensitive to the attacker’s levels of loss aversion and likelihood insensitivity, meaning that understanding such descriptive decision-effects is important in making such decisions. 


Researchers had previously encountered problems finding solutions to game theory models that include loss aversion or likelihood insensitivity. Other researchers had developed approaches where one could always find a solution, but we found that the algorithm could take many hours to solve even simple games. So our research moved from specific counter-terrorism models to a general approach to solving such games. We developed a new approach that guaranteed a solution and was much quicker to find. We also found that our approach better fitted experimental data on human behavior in such situations than the leading approaches.


Finally, we performed some experiments of our own to verify the assumptions commonly made in such research. Specifically, if one assumes that a player exhibits loss aversion or likelihood insensitivity, then one also assumes that the other players share this information in common. As mentioned above, people are found to exhibit loss aversion or likelihood insensitivity in experiments, but if you are not familiar with this research, would you predict that someone else would exhibit such behavior? In our experiments, we found that people exhibited loss aversion or likelihood insensitivity in the same proportions as found in previous experiments. However, we found that the majority of participants made choices that revealed they though other players would choose randomly. Some participants did expect other people to play using expected utility, but less than one-tenth expected the other player to exhibit loss aversion or likelihood insensitivity. 


In summary, we have improved previous approaches to counter-terrorism decision making and game theory. However, our final experiments mean significant further work needs to be performed to develop a complete model of strategic interactions like counter-terrorism decision making. Throughout our project, 11 doctoral students have completed a course combining prescriptive decision analysis with behavioral decision theory. One student completed his doctoral dissertation on this work and a one-year post doctoral position. Three other doctoral students (not funded on this grant) are working on related areas. The work has been presented at 11 conferences and university seminars. Thus far, one paper and one book chapter have been published, one book chapter is in final revision, one paper is submitted, and three more papers are in final preparation for submission. The work has also been widely accepted at the Center for Risk and Economic Analysis of Terrorist Events, a DHS funded center of excellence at the University of Southern California.
